The given Node.js code checks the environment in which the application is running and exports the appropriate module file accordingly. It uses `process.env.NODE_ENV` to determine whether the application is in 'production' or 'development' mode. If it's in 'production', it exports a minified version of the module called `immer.cjs.production.min.js`. If it's in any other environment (typically 'development'), it exports a non-minified version named `immer.cjs.development.js`.

Now, here's the rewritten code:

```javascript
'use strict';

const isProduction = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production';
const modulePath = isProduction ? './immer.cjs.production.min.js' : './immer.cjs.development.js';
module.exports = require(modulePath);
```
